subject: Travel
subcategory: The Story of Maps and Navigation
title: The Sextant and the Stars
description: A 60-second lesson on The Sextant and the Stars.

hook.text: For 300 years, a handheld instrument and the stars were all a captain needed to cross any ocean.

buildup.text: The sextant measures the angle between a celestial body and the horizon, giving exact latitude.

discovery.text: Combined with precise time from a chronometer, a navigator could fix position anywhere on Earth.

twist.text: GPS has made the sextant nearly obsolete. The US Naval Academy stopped teaching it, then brought it back.

climax.text: Military leaders realized GPS can be jammed or spoofed. Celestial navigation is the unjammable backup.

punchline.text: The oldest navigation method is now the backup for the newest.

quiz.question: Why did the US Naval Academy bring back sextant training?
options: GPS can be jammed, so celestial navigation is the backup
